properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 10 to 15 cm of snow is forecast for tonight as a low pressure system moves across the area. The moist airmass will interact with the cooler lower atmosphere to generate lower density snow for a total of 10 to 15 cm. The snow will end overnight as the low moves out of the region. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-06T11:14:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-05T23:01:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0649379485.2020
Area: Whitehorse
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system will bring a mix of precipitation to the Northwest Territories beginning tonight and ending Sunday afternoon. Snow will begin this evening in the central Mackenzie, with the largest snowfall amounts forecast within the Norman Wells, Wrigley, and Deline regions. 5 to 10 cm of snow is expected for these communities by noon on Sunday. Patchy freezing rain is likely from Fort Liard to Fort Providence, and will spread to other regions surrounding Great Slave Lake, including Yellowknife. The greatest chance of freezing precipitation is in the Fort Liard Region. The freezing rain is forecast to begin tonight in Fort Liard and will progress eastwards throughout Sunday morning. Any freezing rain will end or change to snow by Sunday afternoon. There is still some uncertainty in the intensity of this system. Weather warnings may be required as the storm develops. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-06T14:19:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-05T22:20:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1907726660.2020
Area: Ft. Simpson Region including Jean Marie River, Wrigley Region, Norman Wells - Tulita Region, Deline, Ft. Providence Region including Kakisa - Chan Lake, Yellowknife Region, North Slave Region including Wekweeti - Whati - Behchoko, Hay River Region including Enterprise, Thebacha Region including Ft. Smith - Salt River Reserve, Ft. Resolution Region including Hwy. 6, Lutsel K'e Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions will develop Sunday night as an upper warm front brings snow in concert with a very strong easterly surface wind. Easterly winds of 80 km/h gusting to 100 near the Richardson Mountains will generate near zero visibility in snow and blowing snow beginning Sunday evening. Blizzard conditions will end Monday morning as the winds ease. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-06T15:03:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-05T23:04:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2112213488.2020
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, rain and wind is expected tonight, Sunday and Sunday night. Total snowfall: possibly exceeding 20 cm. Total rainfall: 15 to 25 mm. Locations: northeastern New Brunswick. Time span: tonight through Monday morning. Remarks: Snow, rain and ice pellets have moved into northeastern New Brunswick. The rain/snow line will persist through these regions with western sections receiving the most snow and eastern areas receiving the most rain. Precipitation will change to snow throughout these regions Sunday night as colder air moves in. Snow will taper to flurries Monday morning. Additionally, strong northeast winds are expected tonight and Sunday along the Bay de Chaleur and Acadian coasts. A wind warning has been issued for the Acadian Peninsula. Conditions will improve on Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-06T17:29:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T01:30:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1802157884.2020
Area: Miramichi and area, Acadian Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Additional 20 to 30 cm of snow through Sunday night. A series of Pacific frontal systems will move across the region tonight and tomorrow, giving periods of snow, at times heavy. Snowfall accumulation of near 20 cm are expected for each 24 hour period that began early on Friday and will continue through the weekend. The heavy snow will ease late Monday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-06T16:47:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T00:48:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2182360359.2020
Area: South Klondike Highway - Carcross to White Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense low pressure system will track across Eastern Quebec tonight and Sunday. For areas of the North Shore, snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 centimetres are expected from Les Escoumins to Havre-Saint-Pierre, and over the western part of Anticosti Island overnight Sunday. In addition, strong winds gusting to 60 or 70 km/h will accompanying this system will greatly reduce visibilities in blowing snow. Over the Southeastern Gaspe Peninsula, mixed precipitation are expected. Snowfall amounts expected are rather light, as precipitation should change to rain early Sunday morning with 15 to 25 millimetres expected during the day. In addition, there is a risk of freezing precipitation inland beginning overnight through near midday Sunday. Motorists should be prepared to deal with changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-06T12:36:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-05T20:37:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4260647221.2020
Area: Forestville area, Les Escoumins area, Chandler area, New Carlisle - Port-Daniel area, Baie-Comeau, Baie-Trinité area, Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier area, Minganie, Anticosti

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A series of fronts will bring upwards of 150 mm of rain from Bella Bella to Port Renfrew by Tuesday morning. Some areas may reach warning criteria and rainfall warnings may be warranted. However, even in areas where warning level rainfall totals may not be achieved, the total rainfall amount may still trigger localised flooding, debris flow or road washouts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall Sunday night to Monday evening. Locations: Upper Lake Melville area. Sunday night snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Monday snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Remarks: At this time, snowfall accumulations are not expected to reach the warning criteria of 15 cm in 12 hours. However, the possibility remains if the system were to track further north. For travel considerations: A winter storm warning is in effect for the Eagle River section of the Trans-Labrador Highway. Travel is not recommended in that direction from Sunday night through Tuesday morning due to heavy snowfall and reduced visibility in blowing snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 25 to 35 cm. Maximum winds: northeasterly gusting to 60 km/h. Time span: Sunday afternoon until Monday evening. Locations: Eagle River section of the Trans-Labrador Highway. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. The ground, already near saturation, has little ability to absorb further rainfall. Total rainfall: 30 to 60 mm. Locations: southern New Brunswick. Time span: continuing tonight and tapering off throughout the day Sunday. Remarks: Rainfall amounts may be lower than the standard criteria for a rainfall warning; however, the saturated ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Significant pooling and runoff are likely to occur. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-06T16:45:13-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain is falling over the Watson Lake area as warm air aloft overrides cold air at the surface. Up to 5 mm of ice accretion is expected before surface temperatures warm up above zero and the freezing rain changes to rain late this afternoon. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts are expected or occurring Maximum gusts: southeasterly up to 130 km/h in the Wreckhouse area. Time span: early Sunday morning until midday Sunday. Remarks: Strong southeasterly winds gusting to 80 km/h in the Wreckhouse area will develop overnight, and further strengthen to reach near 130 km/h on Sunday morning. Winds will ease Sunday afternoon. ### Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system will give snow at times heavy this evening and Sunday over the Gaspé Peninsula. A total snowfall amount of 20 to 30 centimetres is expected. The combination of snow and strong winds will cause local blowing snow. Weather conditions will improve overnight Sunday night. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A strong Pacific front will approach Haida Gwaii Sunday morning and give rise to southeast winds up to 90 km/h. The winds are expected to shift to southwest and ease considerably in the wake of the front shortly after noon. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 20 to 40 cm of snow, strong winds and blowing snow are expected. An intense low pressure system will affect Eastern Quebec and bring snow at times heavy this evening and Sunday over the Lower St. Lawrence and the Gaspé Peninsula areas. This storm will also be accompanied by strong winds gusting up to 80 kilometres per hour. These winds combined with snow will reduce visibilities to nearly zero locally over these areas beginning tonight. Otherwise, strong winds combined with the high tide could produce breaking sea conditions over the Northeastern coast of the Gaspé Peninsula late in the day Sunday. There is also a risk of freezing rain over the Eastern Gaspé Peninsula Sunday morning. Poor conditions will continue through Monday over the Northern Gaspé Peninsula. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-06T19:33:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T03:34:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0770863290.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintry mix of inland snow and coastal rain is expected. Time span: Sunday night until Monday night. Locations: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm inland and over higher terrain, especially north of Red bay. Total rainfall: 10 to 15 mm along the coast. Remarks: Road conditions will likely deteriorate quickly, especially over areas towards Red Bay and beyond. There is still some uncertainty as to how far north the mild air and rain will extend; a snowfall warning may be required if the track of the weather system changes. For travel considerations: A snowfall warning is in effect for Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, and a winter storm warning is in effect for the Eagle River section of the Trans-Labrador Highway. Travel is not recommended through those areas from Sunday night to Tuesday morning due to heavy snowfall and reduced visibility in blowing snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-06T17:55:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T01:56:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3447755606.2020
Area: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Prolonged significant snowfall expected Sunday night through Tuesday. Total snowfall over a 36-hour period: 30 to 40 cm. Locally higher amounts are possible. Strongest winds: northeasterly gusting to 60 km/h. Locations: Cartwright to Lodge Bay. Remarks: The highest snowfall amounts are expected to be inland and over higher terrain, including sections of the Trans-Labrador highway. Travel will be hazardous over inland routes due to accumulating snow and reduced visibility in blowing snow. Along the coast, especially from Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, temperatures will be near zero, which may cause the snow to mix with or change over to rain on Monday. Accumulations will be lower along the coast. Conditions will likely improve at some point on Tuesday as snow tapers to flurries. For travel considerations: A winter storm warning is in effect for the Eagle River section of the Trans-Labrador Highway. ### Road closures are possible. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-06T17:53:33-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 2 to 5 millimetres of freezing precipitation are expected over parts of the Lower North Shore Sunday morning. ### Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-06T19:33:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T03:34:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0891863867.2020
Area: Natashquan, Chevery, Anticosti
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rainfall expected to continue this evening. A slow moving front over the north coast will continue to bring rain to Stewart. Up to 60 mm of rain has already fallen and an additional 10 to 15 mm is expected before the rain intensity eases tonight. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-06T10:19:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T02:13:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0849467086.2020
Area: North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Fog patches are expected to become dense tonight and continue into overnight before dissipating Sunday morning. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-06T14:50:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T03:52:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0451005227.2020
Area: Red Lake - Woodland Caribou Park, Kenora - Grassy Narrows - Whitedog, Sioux Narrows - Nestor Falls - Morson, Fort Frances - Emo - Rainy River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system will give snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm from this evening through Sunday morning over the eastern part of the Eastern Townships and over higher grounds of the Chaudiere-Appalaches area. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-06T13:59:50-00:00
